..."Eight years ago Ben Bernanke, already a governor at the Federal Reserve although not yet chairman, spoke at a conference honoring Milton Friedman...."

Actually, one could pretty much stop reading right there and know what was coming, Professor Krugman! The fact that Bernanke spoke at an occasion honoring Milton Friedman, founder of the Chicago School, and the Godfather of the Free Market--tells us so very much about the sad plight of our country today, with the rich getting--well you know!

As Naomi Klein wrote in "Shock Doctrine," Milton Friedman's economic policies have reigned supreme since the Reagan era, and certainly were in play before that time. We have occupied countries and supported corrupt dictators in order to enrich the rich in America--and leave the poor poorer wherever they might be. Right now, they just happen to be in our owne country.

But Milton Friedman and his followers (including, very unfortunately, Barack Obama and his two main economic advisers, Larry Summers and Timothy Geithner) have made sure that free market thinking and practices continue. Why? Because hardly anybody understands how the free market is not free at all--that it has cost us our middle class and our hope!

It is time to take to the streets, people!

While you bash China for currency manipulation, the U.S. Fed is printing $600 billion dollars of "quantitative easing" to lower our effective interest rate to a negative 5%.  Who is the real hypocrite here?

My hope is that, with much of the Blue Dog caucus gone and the shellacking the Democrats took largely due to their failure to be bold enough on the economy, that President Obama and the Democrats will finally be bold. They should come out hitting hard with an economic agenda that includes:

* a sufficiently large stimulus proposal

* major new infrastructure investments

* aid to state and local governments that is adequate to get them hiring again

* a WPA-style work program

* cramdown legislation to help people save their homes

* a major shift in the tax burden away from the working and middle classes and toward the wealthy elite

Of course, none of this will get passed with the Republicans gaining control of the House. However, with the Republicans continuing to obstruct everything, economic recovery is not going to occur in the next two years. And President Obama and the Democrats will be blamed unless they have a a bold plan that can set up a clear contrast between them and the obstructionist Republicans for the 2012 elections.

Now, you may be thinking that there is no way the Democrats will be this bold. But that is where we progressives come in. We must make our voices be heard by our elected officials, the Democratic party, the media, and our neighbors by calling the White House, Senators, and Representatives, writing letters to the editors, etc. demanding bold progressive action on the economy. Let's get to it!

http://www.winningprogressive.org

I don't get why people are worried about inflation. Wage increases are dead, and there is no sign of a traditional wage-price inflationary spiral. Commodities prices are set globally, and while they do show some global inflationary pressure, they are not hugely influential in the post-industrial US economy.

Inflation worries are an example of how ideologues have corrupted our national policy debate. These people are in love with their anti-inflation ideology and are resistant to data. Another more sinister possibility is that some people benefit from very low inflation and lobby for it even if it is bad for America. Bond holders, and the Wall Street banks that create bonds, are possible culprits.

Good grief, Professor, if someone who hadn't won the Nobel Prize proposed what you're proposing, he'd be tarred as one of the green ink brigade.
Let me see if I have this straight: you would have the Fed quantitatively ease not less, but more, and more, until the country was awash in enough extra money that had been spun out of thin air for inflation to predictably rise...and that that inflation - manufactured, artificial - would also be a good thing? Well, pardon my skepticism, but you first. Yet again you are throwing your lot in with those who would, through such proposals as these, punish the very people who have done the right thing and lived within their means. They may not have all the gadgetry, the late-model cars, the real estate portfolio that others have, but they also don't have all that debt to service. And now here you come and effectively say, 'no fair - they too must pay. Shame on them for withholding their own money from the economy'.
The 'firestorm of opposition and criticism', as you put it, to this kind of monetary policy, is actually sensible people who realise that what you propose might see some short term benefit, but there is no solid foundation upon which it is built, and will inevitably lead to worse conditions in the future. This crisis MUST be allowed to resolve itself naturally (which will seem too slowly for some) and - crucially - with real accountability for the profligates who got us in this mess, or we'll all be back here again, and sooner than we think.

Certainly, the Fed's actions to buy long term debt will weaken our currency and address our trade imbalances, however, there's a practical reason why this won't result in lower interest rates for consumers; particularly those buying homes. The new regulatory regime, coupled with massive consolidation of market share in the mortgage lending industry has given pricing power to lenders over consumers.

Mortgage rates would be 20-60 bps lower on average if they reflected a real relationship between costs of borrowing for institutions. However, due to the circumstance of Bank of America and Wells Fargo controlling well over 40% of the national market for whole loan origination (through retail, broker and bank to bank channels) there is a stunning lack of pricing competition. Furthermore, Bank of America closed it's Wholesale Broker channel this past month, again, aiming to increase its retail lending at higher margins.

Ultimately, too big to fail is translating in large enough to cause failure for the mortgage industry. Higher rates mean that all of this monetary policy still won't be enough to cause a more rapid absorption of distressed real estate into the homeowner market.

Maybe they're Tin Men, maybe they're just Cowardly Lions. Or maybe, like the Scarecrow, they just don't have brains.

If the Fed isn't going to do anything meaningful, then the President must. Mitch McConnell has repeatedly said that his main objective is to bring down the President. He's left the President with a couple of pretty good sound bites. The President must take advantage of Republican "candor" and post-midterm hubris.

But President Obama suggested after his Cabinet meeting last week & again, aired on "60 Minutes" last night, that he wasn't going to do that. He said Republicans (and he) behaved badly during the campaign, but he hoped they would behave better now. Yeah, I'm expecting Mitch McConnell to go all cuddly and cooperative any minute now.

When people complain that President Obama doesn't have passion, those Charlie Brown moments are what they're talking about. Nobody wants a President who rants and raves and totally loses it. That's why McCain lost the election. But we want a President who has the passion to fight for us. When the opposition repeatedly promises to do the bidding of the rich and do nothing for the rest of us, somebody besides Bernie Sanders and Michael Moore has to stand up for us.

We have known for some time that Ben Bernanke wasn't going to do it. We know Harry Reid can't do it. So that somebody has to be the President. That's what we hired him to do. He must shed his Charlie Brown optimism, and be as bold as the adversaries of the people. The President has to devise catchy slogans for every one of their proposals and repeat the slogans so often even the dense will understand. He has to go on Fox "News" and repeat them so even the Foxbots will hear them. He has to repeat them on camera and right in the faces of Mitch McConnell & Eric Cantor. The President's fiscal policies may be complex, but he must reduce them to populist slogans. And he must do so now.

I know Ben Bernanke is a Republican, so I'm not surprised he won't do anything serious to jolt the economy. Many of us suspect President Obama is a Republican, too. He's nearly run out of chances to prove he's a Democrat. If he's going to do it, he will have to do it now.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

What, then, is the point of the Fed's Board of Governors (one dissenter on the policy) and the notion of the Fed's independence from the political branches if the Fed makes policy and then Bernanke sticks his finger in the air to assess the political winds? He has been Obamaed, I  agree: you've coined a useful verb to describe someone who is weak, sniveling, unnecessarily cowed, and afraid to fail. If I may employ a homely metaphor from the world of sport: when much is riding on your play, you never want to leave the putt short. Better to skull it here, Ben.

Those who practice the politics of suffering strike blows intended to wound every good effort to increase economic demand. Without increased demand, there will be no jobs growth. But the Chicken Littles who proclaim the sky is falling look only in one direction for shelter: tax cuts. Theirs is a one note world view.

The administration needs an immediate, massive public education effort, undertaken by leading economists, and yes, the effort can be bi-partisan, to examine the views of economic policy, and of those who mislead policy discussions by irrelevant examples, fallacies in logic, distortions of history, and old fashion appeals to fear. It is amazing that most news programs now only have single guest experts whose job is to “interpret” the policy proposals for a $14 trillion dollar economy in sound bites less than 120 seconds long.

The omission of facts, charts, graphs, and other visual aids in a visual medium is clearly intended to be deceptive and spread half-truths that have a full measure of fear and suffering. Economics is a dismal science not because its principles are muddled or unworkable; instead its sound body of developed knowledge and applications is clouded by those who alter and deliberately mis-read facts and exchange them for a currency of apprehension and distress, while sending links and posts to each other to congratulate themselves on the success of their efforts. But their success continues to be the country's downfall. Jobs will not come except from demand; and evil can not beget good.
--Walter Rhett

Weakening the dollar will help our economy slightly in the sense that we will have to pay more for imports, and therefore we may import less goods. And, raising the prices a little on imported gooods would help domestic industries compete slightly better. But on the other hand, our oil imports will most likely cost more, and this would put a damper on our economy, probably offsetting any economic benefits derived from a weaker dollar.

The real problem is that we have deindustrialized our country to such an extent that essentially all monetary policies are going to be ineffective in the long run as a means of causing a sustained long-term boost to our economy.

This is why the Bush tax cuts could not keep us out of a recession, why the first stimulus did not keep our unemployment numbers from rising to the ten percent range, and why the other actions such as allowing banks to borrow money for interest rates of nearly zero percent have not caused an economic recovery. And the "quantative easing" that you speak of will also fail. We are not in a typical cyclic recession. We are in a structual recession which can not be treated with monetary action as those cyclic recessions of the past.

Our structual recession was caused by moving tens of thousands of factories to China and elsewhere. Taking our industrial heartland and turning it into the "rust belt" has economic consequences. And our structual recession can not be cured by tweaking our monetary policy, as we have seen. The only solution is to stop the destruction of our economy caused by the deindustrialization of America.

Our country is a rich country, and we are living off our past wealth creation. But our wealth and prosperity are rapidly being transferred to China, and it will be gone one day. We must stop imports from low-wage countries before our economy is totally destroyed.

Frank Mitchell
